newsitem.title: ITALY: Madonna dedicates Italy premiere to Mastroianni.
newsitem.headline: Madonna dedicates Italy premiere to Mastroianni.

text.p: Pop singer turned actress Madonna on Friday dedicated the Italian premiere of the film musical Evita to actor Marcello Mastroianni, the quintessential Latin lover who died on Thursday.

"I would also like to dedicate this screening to Marcello Mastroianni, a beautiful man, a great artist and one of the greatest gifts Italy has ever given the world," Madonna told viewers before the premiere in Rome.
Spanish actor Antonio Banderas, who plays Argentine revolutionary Che Guevara in the film, also dedicated the premiere to the Italian actor.
Mastroianni, who portrayed the Latin lover in many of his 160 post-war films, died of cancer in his Paris apartment on Thursday, aged 72.
He was perhaps best known for playing the suave reporter in Federico Fellini's 1959 classic "La Dolce Vita" (The Sweet Life) alongside Swedish bombshell Anita Eckberg.
Madonna arrived in Rome on Friday for the Italian premiere of Evita, which was released last Saturday in Los Angeles and is already spawning talk of Oscars.
Madonna plays Argentina's late Eva Peron in the film, a screen version of the Andrew Lloyd Webber musical.

Madonna, wearing dark glasses and a headscarf, held her three-month-old baby Lourdes Maria Ciccone Leon in her arms as she emerged from Rome's Ciampino airport into the glare of television lights and photographers' flashes.
The child was hidden from view behind a white shawl. Screaming fans waiting for the star outside Rome's swish Hotel Hassler were acknowledged with a smile from Madonna but not a glimpse of her baby.
The father, Carlos Leon, is the star's personal trainer.
